Description: Reconstructed (from numerous fragments and much added plaster) South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: reserved band at top of rim, glazed brown below with trace of added red lines; exterior: streaky brown band on rim and upper part of shoulder, reserved below; streaky brown band around edge of foot and on exterior of handle root.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B1 (possibly)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, the shape, fabric, and decoration find parallels with his Type 11,3.A South Ionian cup with everted rim. See British Museum 1886,0401.669. Very few Type 11 cups were found at Naukratis and Schlotzhauer suggests that these may have been made in specific workshops that rarely exported vases to Naukratis. The place of production of Type 11 South Ionian cups is determined as Miletus based on the results of NAA analysis carried out by Hans Mommsen, Bonn, on another sherd (British Museum 1886,0401.570) from Naukratis and of same shape, decoration, and fabric.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 228, no. 141)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 119 no.. 333 pl. XXXVII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.247) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4821 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
